Award.AwardTitle: Climate Change in the Upper Atmosphere
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will explore climate change in the upper atmosphere, based on long-term incoherent scatter radar (ISR) observations of the ionosphere. This study used ion temperature (Ti) data which gives a direct measurement of the upper atmosphere thermal status since it is very close to the neutral thermosphere temperature (Tn) from 100 km up the F2 peak region. Preliminary studies targeting the altitude region between 350-400 km above the Millstone Hill Incoherent Scatter Radar shows a clear decreasing trend in Ti which agrees with theoretical calculations for the greenhouse effect. This project will provide a height profile of the trend from the lower (E-region) to the higher (F-region) part of the ionosphere, and will in addition to the Millstone Hill radar use data from another mid-latitude site (St. Santin). Sondrestrom and Chatanika/Poker Flat, both at high latitudes, will also be utilized to demonstrate the geographic extent of the trends, and to provide insight into the origin of the climate change in the upper atmosphere.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explores the climate change in the upper atmosphere, based on long-term incoherent scatter radar (ISR) observations (supported by NSF) of the ionosphere, in particular, the ion temperature Ti. Ionospheric plasma temperatures are some essential measures of the upper atmospheric thermal status. Ion temperature at 250 km and below is very close to neutral temperature, and therefore it is directly relevant to the thermosphere. Thermospheric density, which is regulated by neutral  temperature, has important impact on the satellite orbiting via atmospheric drag. Thus characterizing ionospheric temperature long-term trends and understaing the associated plausible mechenisms are important subject area. 

 

The unique ISR long-term datasets have allowed us to characterize the ionospheric trends in various parameters, including ion temperature, and the important height dependency within 100-500 km. The analysis covered 3 ISR sites, including Millstone Hill for ~50 years at midlatitude, Sondrestrom for 20 +  years at high latitudes, and Chatanika/Poker Flat spanning ~40 years at auroral latitudes. Figure 1 summarizes the ion trends derived from the datasets.

 

The aggregate radar observations have very comparable and consistent altitude dependence of long-term trends. In particular, the lower F region (< 275 km) exhibits dayside cooling trends that are significantly higher (−3 to −1 K/yr at 250 km) than anticipated from model predictions given the anthropogenic increase of greenhouse gases. Above 275 km, cooling trends continue to increase in magnitude but values are strongly dependent on magnetic latitude, suggesting the presence of significant downward influences from nonneutral atmospheric processes.

 

The most significant result lies in the trend magnitude being much larger than the anticipated CO2 increasing effect. This imposes a important question regarding the relative importance of various factors that may contribute to long-term trends in the ionosphere and thermosphere. While the CO2 long-term change influences are generally global, the influences from secular changes in the earth's main magnetic field may be strongly location dependence due to the spatial inhomogeneity of the changes and effects. Most recent GCM simulations (paper in preparation by a collaborator) which include long-term changes in both CO2 and earth's main field suggest that these large cooling trends in the radar observations can be well related to the magnetic main filed changes. Specifically at Millstone Hill, the site has been gradually moving away from the auroral zone with the magnetic latitude and dip amgle being smaller. This has a number of consequences at Millstone Hill, including the reduced heating to the upper atmosphere, and reduced electron density because of being closer to the midlatitude trough as well as reduced equatorward disturbance winds. The reduced electron density can potentially lead to less heat transfer from electrons to the ions. It appears that ISR observations provide fresh and highly visible evidence  of influences of secular changes in the earth's magentic field. 

 

This project has succesfully achived the proposed scientific goals with important scientific results.  With a very small team,  it has generated two dozens of scientific publications and presentations. 5 REU students are involved in the research. It also allows for some extensive international and demostic collaborations on the study of upper atmospheric climate change.
